fr:mainmatter.html:p: A point \mathbf {x_{\star }} is a stationary point of f(\cdot ), if \nabla f(\mathbf {x_{\star }})\ =\ \mathbf {0}. Here, \mathbf {x_{\star }} is also known as a critical point.

html:ul.html:li:
First order necessary condition: If \ \mathbf {x_{\star }} is a local minimizer of \ f:\mathbb {R}^{n}\mapsto \mathbb {R}, and f is continuously differentiable in an open neighborhood of \ \mathbf {x_{\star }}, then we must have  oxed {
abla f(\mathbf {x_{\star }})\ =\ \mathbf {0}.}
Second order necessary condition: If \mathbf {x_{\star }} is a local minimizer of f:\mathbb {R}^{n}\mapsto \mathbb {R}, and f is twice continuously differentiable in an open neighborhood around \mathbf {x_{\star }}, then we must have (i)\ 
abla f(\mathbf {x_{\star }})=\mathbf {0}; (ii)\ 
abla ^{2}f(\mathbf {x_{\star }})\succeq \mathbf {0}.
If 
abla ^{2}f(\mathbf {x_{\star }})\succ \mathbf {0} then the above is a sufficient condition.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter:
Let f:\mathbb {R}^{n}\mapsto \mathbb {R} be a convex function, then
A local minimizer of f is also its global minimizer. If f is strictly convex, the global minimizer is unique
A point is a global minimizer of f iff \mathbf {0}\ \in \ \partial f(\mathbf {x_{\star }}). If f\in \mathcal {C}^{1}, then \nabla f(\mathbf {x_{\star }})=\mathbf {0} implies that \mathbf {x_{\star }} is a global minimizer.
